cs567.smoke
Class FluidSolver

java.lang.Object
  cs567.smoke.FluidSolver

public class FluidSolver
extends java.lang.Object

Jos Stam style fluid solver with vorticity confinement and buoyancy force.

public void reset()

buoyancy

public void buoyancy(float[] Fbuoy,
                     float alpha)
Calculate the buoyancy force as part of the velocity solver. Fbuoy = -a*d*Y + b*(T-Tamb)*Y where Y = (0,1). The constants a and b are positive with appropriate (physically meaningful) units. T is the temperature at the current cell, Tamb is the average temperature of the fluid grid. The density d provides a mass that counteracts the buoyancy force. In this simplified implementation, we say that the tempterature is synonymous with density (since smoke is *hot*) and because there are no other heat sources we can just use the density field instead of a new, seperate temperature field.

Parameters:
Fbuoy - Array to store buoyancy force for each cell.
alpha - Scaling factor (old: alpha=1)

curl

public float curl(int i,
                  int j)
Calculate the curl at position (i, j) in the fluid grid. Physically this represents the vortex strength at the cell. Computed as follows: w = (del x U) where U is the velocity vector at (i, j).

Parameters:
i - The x index of the cell.
j - The y index of the cell.

getDensity

float[] getDensity()
Fragile reference to the density field.

vorticityConfinement

public void vorticityConfinement(float[] Fvc_x,
                                 float[] Fvc_y)
Calculate the vorticity confinement force for each cell in the fluid grid. At a point (i,j), Fvc = N x w where w is the curl at (i,j) and N = del |w| / |del |w||. N is the vector pointing to the vortex center, hence we add force perpendicular to N.

Parameters:
Fvc_x - The array to store the x component of the vorticity confinement force for each cell.
Fvc_y - The array to store the y component of the vorticity confinement force for each cell.

velocitySolver

public void velocitySolver()
The basic velocity solving routine as described by Stam, with some hooks for target-driven smoke control.

densitySolver

project

void project(float[] x,
             float[] y,
             float[] p,
             float[] div)
Use project() to make the velocity a mass conserving, incompressible field. Achieved through a Hodge decomposition. First we calculate the divergence field of our velocity using the mean finite differnce approach, and apply the linear solver to compute the Poisson equation and obtain a "height" field. Now we subtract the gradient of this field to obtain our mass conserving velocity field.

Parameters:
x - The array in which the x component of our final velocity field is stored.
y - The array in which the y component of our final velocity field is stored.
p - A temporary array we can use in the computation.
div - Another temporary array we use to hold the velocity divergence field.

linearSolver

Iterative linear system solver using the Gauss-Seidel relaxation technique. TODO: REPLACE THIS METHOD WITH BETTER PCG SOLVER!
